message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in one ear, along with the results of the Weber test (lateralization to the affected ear) and Rinne test (air conduction greater than bone conduction) suggest the most likely diagnosis is acoustic neuroma. Other options such as presbycusis and cerumen impaction typically do not present with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, and Ménière disease typically presents with vertigo in addition to hearing loss and tinnitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in one ear suggest acoustic neuroma. The Weber test, in which the vibration tuning fork is placed on the forehead, shows lateralization to the contralateral ear in cases of unilateral conductive hearing loss or ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss. The Rinne test, in which the tuning fork is held first on the mastoid bone and then in front of the ear canal, allows to distinguish sensorineural from conductive hearing loss. In this case, the Rinne test shows sensorineural hearing loss in both ears.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the Weber test results suggest acoustic neuroma. Presbycusis and cerumen impaction would not cause tinnitus or progressive hearing loss, and the Weber test would not be abnormal in these conditions. Ménière disease is a possibility but it typically presents with vertigo as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss suggest a possible diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The results of the Weber and Rinne tests, with hearing better in the ear with the tuning fork placed over the ear, also suggests nerve damage. Presbycusis is a common age-related hearing loss, while cerumen impaction can cause temporary hearing loss but usually does not cause tinnitus. Ménière disease typically presents with vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a nerve conduction issue in the left ear. The Weber test shows lateralization to the left ear which suggests that the left ear is picking up the sound more than the right ear. This, along with the patient's history of progressive hearing loss, indicates acoustic neuroma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acoustic neuroma, and the Rinne test and Weber test further support this diagnosis. Presbycusis is age-related hearing loss and is unlikely in this patient. Cerumen impaction can cause hearing loss but not tinnitus, and would not affect the results of the Rinne and Weber tests. Ménière disease would cause tinnitus and hearing loss, but not the specific pattern of the Rinne and Weber tests seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's tinnitus, progressive hearing loss, and the Weber test results are suggestive of an acoustic neuroma. Other options like presbycusis and cerumen impaction would not explain the progressive hearing loss and the Weber test results. Ménière disease typically has symptoms of vertigo and is unlikely to cause progressive hearing loss in only one ear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in one ear suggest a possible diagnosis of acoustic neuroma, which is confirmed by the Weber and Rinne tuning fork tests showing lateralization to the affected ear. Presbycusis is a gradual hearing loss due to aging and is unlikely in a patient with progressive hearing loss over only 6 months. Cerumen impaction can cause temporary hearing loss but would not be a cause of tinnitus. Ménière disease is characterized by vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus, but the Weber and Rinne tests would not show lateralization to one ear in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss, along with the Weber and Rinne tests suggesting conductive hearing loss in the left ear, indicate that the most likely diagnosis is acoustic neuroma. Presbycusis is a gradual age-related hearing loss that affects both ears, while cerumen impaction typically causes ear pain or pressure. Ménière disease typically involves episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tuning fork test suggests that the patient has conductive hearing loss in the left ear, which could be caused by an acoustic neuroma. Presbycusis is age-related hearing loss and would not cause the conductive hearing loss observed with the tuning fork test. Cerumen impaction can cause temporary conductive hearing loss but it would not last for 6 months. Meniere disease is associated with vertigo, which was not reported by the patient.
